questions.question: What is the empirical formula of STAM-1?
What method was used to analyze single crystals of STAM-1?
questions.answer: Single crystals of STAM-1 were analyzed using a Rigaku Mercury CCD equipped with graphite monochromated Mo-KÎ± radiation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the esterification process in the synthesis of STAM-1?
questions.answer: The esterification process during the synthesis of STAM-1 selectively forms the mono-methyl derivative of BTC, leading to a material with unique hydrophilic and hydrophobic channels.

questions.question: How does the adsorption behavior of STAM-1 differ between CO2 and methanol?
questions.answer: CO2 shows lower total pore volumes indicating adsorption in one type of pore, while methanol shows higher accessible volumes and a gated adsorption process, indicating adsorption in both types of pores.

questions.question: What role does copper play in the synthesis of STAM-1?
questions.answer: Copper is vital for the esterification process during the synthesis of STAM-1, as replacing copper with other metals does not result in the same esterification process.

questions.question: What structural change occurs in STAM-1 upon dehydration?
questions.answer: Upon dehydration, STAM-1 undergoes a subtle structural change that lowers its symmetry from trigonal to triclinic and closes one of the channels.

questions.question: Can STAM-1 be used as a protecting group for selective transformations?
questions.answer: Yes, STAM-1 acts as a protecting group for two of the three carboxylic acid units of BTC, enabling functionalization of only one of the acid groups and demonstrating a high-yielding synthetic methodology.

questions.question: What is the effect of exposing dehydrated STAM-1 to water or methanol?
questions.answer: Exposing dehydrated STAM-1 to water or methanol reverses the structural changes that occurred upon dehydration, reopening the closed channel.
